fields.description: Would like to request that a Log Work link or button be included in the Issue Header. Scrolling to the bottom of the left navigation to log work is inefficient and slows down work log updates.
fields.summary: Add keyboard shortcut for Log Work operation
Create a jira.field.resolution.include transition attribute
Filter for "stale" issues

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-16431].
  {panel}

The following two velocity context docs need an overhaul. They information in them is not entirely accurate.

* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Contents+of+the+Velocity+Context
* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Velocity+Context+for+Email+Templates

Talk to Anton and Justus.
fields.summary: Velocity Context docs need an overhaul
Custom field with type key of other project - multi project picker custom field
Document which content can be internationalised to multiple languages and which can only be internationalised to a single language

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa} *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-16405]. {panel} URL links in subscriptions messages viewed in gmail are corrupted. Steps needed to replicate the problem: # Configure email subscription to be send out from JIRA as *text*. # View a subscription email in gmail. !gmail.png|thumbnail! # Hoover your mouse over the first link to a JIRA case The URL will say something similar to: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-33896JSP-34022 instead of https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-33896 content of the text formatted email {noformat} Issue Subscription Filter: MY- Recently resolved (3days) issues (2 issues) Subscriber: bdziedzic Key Summary JSP-33896 Default Dashboard https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-33896 JSP-34022 Unable to setup Trusted Applicatoin https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-34022 You may edit this subscription at: https://support.atlassian.com/secure/FilterSubscription!default.jspa?subId=10450&filterId=12838 {noformat} HTML source of the gmail page: {noformat}
Issue Subscription
Filter: MY- Recently resolved (3days) issues (2 issues)
Subscriber: bdziedzic

Key         Summary
JSP-33896   Default Dashboard
           https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-33896
JSP-34022   Unable to setup Trusted Applicatoin
           https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-34022

You may edit this subscription at:
https://support.atlassian.com/secure/FilterSubscription!default.jspa?subId=10450& amp;filterId=12838

{noformat} A possible workaround this issue is to switch ON the HTML email notification in JIRA (in the user profile preferences).
fields.summary: gmail corrupts URL in subscription emails

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-16390].
  {panel}

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-16335].
  {panel}

Due to browser security it is not possible to prefill the file upload input boxes. So if the attachment field appears on e.g. Create Issue screen, and an error is detected with user input, the user is returned on to the Creat Issue form and is asked to correct their input.

The trouble is that the file attachments are lost, as we are not able to prefll the file inout boxes. Even if we were able to do that, the files would be uploaded the second time, which is a waste of time and bandwidth,

The solution is to keep the files on the server side and attach them once the input is validated.

The UI should let the user know that the files have been uploaded and also should allow the user to upload extra files and cancel attaching existing (already uploaded) files.
fields.summary: Keep uploaded files even if the issue operation has been submitted so they do not have to be uploaded again

We're not on JIRA yet (hopefully soon), but couldn't keep myself from entering a new feature request:
It would be great if there would be a Visual Studio (.NET) IDE integration for JIRA.

A suggested feature for such integration:
- Allow the developer to associate the VS project with JIRA 'components' (association would be saved in the VS project file)
- Make the list of issues for those components easily accessible

Then you immediately see which issues/tasks you can fix along with the things you were already planning to do.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-16258].
  {panel}

Issue's status and resolution together defines "state" for an issue. For example, issue can be OPEN(Unresolved), RESOLVED(Fixed, Obsolete, etc.)  or CLOSED(Fixed, Obsolete, etc.).

There is a difference for an issue being in status RESOLVED with resolution Fixed compared to situation where the issue is in status CLOSED with resolution Fixed. For example, if a bug issue is RESOLVED (Fixed) the bug may be fixed, but when the issue is CLOSED(Fixed) the bug is both fixed AND verified (someone has checked that the fix really fixes the bug). Of course this depends how do you model your bug reporting process within Jira, but I guess you got the point.

Anyway, the problem is that the roadmap report does not tell state of issues that well. Yes, it shows the resolution, but for the status all you can see is the icon. See attached image for reference.

So, a significant improvement would be if you can make Roadmap report customizable (just like it's possible to customize view for sub-tasks in parent issue, see http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-16098). So, basically I would like to configure which fields are shown and in which order in the roadmap report.

Or is this already possible somehow?
fields.summary: Make the Roadmap report customizable

The user browser's auto-complete feature is great, but can be even better. I propose improving it (along with a setting) to enable searching users based on their properties. A simple use case could be that we have an additional username (or say why not a phone number) attached to the user as a property. When selecting a user using the auto-complete functionality one would want to be able to use these properties when searching a user.

Say John Smith (jsmith) has a phone number defined using the property "phoneNumber" with a value "12345". When searching for him using the auto-complete feature, one could use any of the following (the last one being the new feature):
John
Smith
jsm
123

This should be relatively easy to implement, as this only requires adding a bit of code to the DefaultUserPickerSearchService's userMatches function. The user object is already fetched so we already have the properties in the object.

Adding a setting to enable/disable searching these properties would require a bit more coding but would still be fairly trivial to implement.
fields.summary: Search user properties when searching a user with the user auto-completion functionality

This is the code included in the issue create template for text emails:
#if ($issue.getPriorityObject() && $issue.getPriorityObject().getId() != $constantsManager.getDefaultPriority().getString("id"))
>$stringUtils.leftPad($i18n.getText("issue.field.priority"), $padSize): $issue.getPriorityObject().getNameTranslation($i18n)
#end

The "$issue.getPriorityObject().getId() != $constantsManager.getDefaultPriority().getString("id"))" does not exist in the HTML mail template.  Incoming emails for issues set at the default priority level do not show such priority level in the message body/text.  Please consider removing the "$issue.getPriorityObject().getId() != $constantsManager.getDefaultPriority().getString("id"))" condition from the issuecreated.vm template

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-15907].
  {panel}

Would like to collect and display usage statistics.  Who is using system and when.   This would be to justify use of system to management.  Would like to show numbers as to how many are actually using the system.

5/7/09  Here is an example of a script used to create statistics information on confluence users:
There are no access_logs for confluence. However searching the apache access_log on the proxy shows following for september: 
grep '\/confluence\/login\.action' fchssl-access_log.1|wc -l 
   4633 

There may be a combination of GET and POST with login for Confluence. 
Thus one would have to cut count about in half. 
grep 'GET' temp.txt|wc -l 
   2662 

For jira, it appears that we could get login stats - ie. how many login - by counting number of calles to login.jsp in the access log for tomcat. 
grep '\/jira\/login\.jsp' access_log.2008-05-*|wc -l 
4564 

Ideally we could get statistics from a table with a sql statement such as :
select count(distinct(username)), to_char(calltime,'Mon YYYY') 
 from apache_access 
where calltime>to_date('1-01-2009','MM-DD-YYYY') 
and responsecode not in (302,404) 
group by to_char(calltime,'Mon YYYY') 

So, we'd be recording call-time, username, response code (http response code for call), etc.  If there were other types of calls that the site allows, such as calls to perl or php routines or python, etc., you could have a 'url' column, and add to the query a select on the type of ur.
Example:
...
and url like '%.php%'
...
Sample Output:
                      587 Apr 2009 
                     1480 Feb 2009 
                     1500 Jan 2009 
                     1459 Mar 2009 



and responsecode not in (302,404)
fields.summary: collect and display usage statistics

Dave Meyer

Regression of JRA-1495
version update: affects 5.1.8 and 5.2.2

Currently, in order to share a filter or dashboard with a specific project role, the user must be in that project role.  This means that a project administrator cannot create shared items for a project role unless they are also in that project role.

This should also apply to groups.  Currently, a user can only share filters with groups that they're a member of.  This should respect the 'Browse Users' global permission and if the user has this permission show all groups in the system.

  {panel}

Hello!

We develop our internal management system at the company I work, and it has Jira intergration.
Last Friday we upgraded to the newest version of Jira and found out that one very nice feature doesn't work anymore: retrieving user's open issues.

It took us some time to find out that the problem is that the getSavedFilters method from the JiraSoapService has been deprecated and only returns the user's favourite filters, hence all our users must mark this filter as favourite which is quite annoying from the user perspective.

I don't understand why the removal of a service to retrieve all filters.
Is it possible to have a service like this again?

Thanks.
fields.summary: Add service to retrieve all Jira Filters

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-15851].
  {panel}

I have struggled with installing JIRA on solaris for almost the whole week. I came very close to giving up. I am going to have a go at doing it on Windoze using the standalone JIRA version first. I have found that there is alot more documentation on this. Plus there is a nice windoze install wizard that seems to take you from start to finish. I have high hopes about this.

So my enhancement request is, please provide an install GUI for Unix.

I realise that every Unix machine is different, this may mean that the GUI has to prompt for all sorts of things that are not needed on windoze. But IMO it should still be doable. I also realise it is a pain to have to develop such GUIs because there is no standard infrastructure/machinery for installing stuff on Unix. But the pain I have experienced trying to get JIRA working on solaris is the most amount of pain I have ever experienced setting up software on Unix. Googling just revealed other people experiencing similar amounts of pain in similar areas. Hopefully a nice GUI would make that pain go away.

Linux is slowly moving to install GUIs for complex software. Consider how the kernel or X11 is configured. Although it can be done by editing ASCII config files most people do it through a GUI these days. Over time I think more and more linux software will come with a GUI installer.

I said all this in the JIRA forum and the response was that I should raise an enhancement issue, so here it is. Note that I did eventually get it working on solaris.

Regards,

Andrew Marlow
fields.summary: JIRA on unix would really benefit from a GUI installer

We have found a little bit unexpected behavior with an email handling.
For example, we have a configured Email handler for projectKey=PROJECT_A. This handler processes email message with a PROJECT_B-1234 issue key in message subject. So, handler adds this message as a comment for the PROJECT_B-1234 issue instead of creating a new ticket for the project PROJECT_A. 
Is this a correct flow? Is there any way to change the handler behavior via some configuration parameters (without changing of the Jira source code)?

When a user does not have correct permissions for an action in a jelly script a non informative error is emitted

I had a scipt which had the following:

<jira:TransitionWorkflow key="${keyvar}" user="missinguserfromorig" workflowAction="Resolve issue" resolution="Fixed" assignee="-automatic-" comment="No repro. ." groupLevel="jira-users" />

That resulted in:

2008-09-30 17:50:37,464 http-8080-4 ERROR [web.action.util.JellyRunner] Could not run script.
org.apache.commons.jelly.JellyTagException: file:/c:/foo.xml:52861:0: <jira:TransitionWorkflow> The following problems were found:
Action 5 is invalid

missinguserfromorig  was in jira-users  but not in jira-developers  (two groups that exist on our jira instance).

Adding missinguserfromorig to jira-developers causes the above error to not occur.  

But the error message doesn't lead one to think that would be the problem.   I spent some time thinking the workflow was broken in some arcane way.
fields.summary: When a user does not have correct permissions for an action in a jelly script a non informative error is emitted

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-15695].
  {panel}

All Jelly errors should have the line number of the jelly script and the text which caused the error

When you are using jelly to import lots of issues you will invariably have something that causes the parser / verification to take issue.

Currently, most of the resulting errors do not emit the line number in the jelly file which caused the error.   And there the tears of pain begin.  

So without a line number you are left to binary search by removing portions of your jelly script until you find the line which caused the error.


So the jelly error mechanic needs to emit the line number and the text which caused the error.   And with that debugging and fixing jelly imports will become a lot easier.  Almost trivial you might say :-)
fields.summary: All Jelly errors should have the line number of the jelly script and the text which caused the error

*Original Description*
Hi,

Would it be possible to include a dynamic reply-to field in email notifications being sent by JIRA? The value would be the real email address of the Reporter of the issue (or the person that changes the issue), taken from JIRA's User database. That way, when somebody is on vacation and he gets an email, his out-of-office message could be sent to the creator of the JIRA ticket, in which case the Reporter can decide to assign the issue to somebody else...

Thanks.

This is a placeholder issue for Brads 20% time project.

My goal is to place coarse performance instrumentation into JIRA  and record this into RRD database.

From those RRD stats, graphs of general performance will be made available to admins and to JIRA support staff.

Initially the instrumentation will be very coarse.  eg num of web requests, time of web requests, time of database requests etc..  This may change over time.  

The goal is that instrumentation will have virtually no effect on JIRA performance.
fields.summary: Performance Instrumentation of JIRA.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-15553].
  {panel}

As noted in https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-27005, the single biggest performance issue when scaling Jira to a large number of issues comes from inefficient date sorting performance in Lucene.

The strategy to solving this is essentially the same strategy described in JRA-15549.  Upon any change to an issue, a new Lucene IndexReader/Searcher object should be generated in the background and "pre-warmed" by doing any search that triggers a sort on a date field.  Once the object is ready, the active object should be swapped out for the newly generated one.

There is a trade-off here in that search results could potentially be a few seconds out-of-date, but interactive performance of searches that sort on dates should be greatly improved.

It is possible that JRA-15517 *might* make this feature unnecessary, but I won't be able to report on that until Jira 4.0 is released.
fields.summary: Implement Lucene IndexReader/Searcher queue

When navigating to the following URL:

https://<hostname>/secure/ConfigureReport.jspa?projectOrFilterId=filter-12770&statistictype=customfield_10000&reportKey=com.atlassian.jira.ext.charting%3Asinglefieldpie-report&Next=Next#dataTable

when no "remember me" has been checked (i.e. the user will not get automatically logged in) and then following the login link and logging in an error occurs (user is redirected to 500 page).

I believe the problem is that %3A gets doubly escaped. We need to investigate more. The bug is probably in Seraph.

Please note that the actual example here uses the charting plugin. I am guessing that it has nothing to do with the plugin, but would break for any report URL due to the %3A being in the URL.

JIRA's HTML update emails make use of columns.  The left-hand column (Issue, key, issue type, etc.) takes up about 40% of the screen.  The right-hand column is the body, and takes up about 60% of the screen.  the fields (reporter type, new comment, etc.) often have fixed indent sizes.

The result of that formatting is that the actual content of the alert is only one character wide.  It creates a gigantic vertical scroll, reading a long, vertical sentence.

Workaround: use plain text emails.  use a different email client.

Still, it would be nice if I could view my emails on my iPhone.
fields.summary: improve HTML email readability in mobile devices like iPhone - make column sizes relative

  {panel}

If one needs to be able to restart each individual JIRA webapp without affecting any other webapp (JIRA or any other webapp), a single JIRA webapp should be configured per JVM (and therefore per Tomcat instance).

If restarting multiple webapps at the same time is not an issue, then running multiple webapps in the same Tomcat (and therefore JVM) instance is fine.

We should mention these points in the requirements section of JIRA documentation.

The reloading of webapps in Tomcat is very tricky to get working and does not work with JIRA, leading to OutOfMemoryErrors after a few reloads - JRA-15489.
fields.summary: Document that for maximum flexibility one should run one webvapp per JVM

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-15431].
  {panel}

h3. The Problem

Permissions on the support projects in https://support.atlassian.com (SAC) are configured to allow all actions to Atlassian and to the reporter (the customer), and no access to anyone else. That is customers can only see and do stuff on their own cases.

(Actually we also allow access to all members of the CC multi-user custom field, so that we can add in work colleagues of the reporter.)

This also, of course, applies to [comments added to an issue via email|http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/issue_creation_email.html]. An email containing an issue key will be added as a comment on the issue, but only if the email address matches a user who is the reporter of the issue or Atlassian (or a member of the CC field).

However with this configuration, the following use case is a problem:
# Customer gets an email notification from one of their cases in [SAC|https://support.atlassian.com]. For example, the support engineer has responded to their case.
# The customer's email client is configured so that their email address is set to a different one to their email address in SAC, often an email alias. For example, if their account in SAC has email address fsmith@example.com, the email address in their email client might be fred.smith@example.com.
# The customer replies to the email.
# SAC receives the email and:
## checks to see if there is a user with that email address
## _creates a user if there isn't one_
## then rejects the reply because the user does not have access to the issue. (The user for fsmith@example.com may have been the reporter, but the user for fred.smith@example.com does not have permission.)
## forwards it to the mail handler forward address for a human to deal with the error
# One of our triage engineers deals with the error by manually adding the email content as a comment to the email, adds any attachments in the email, and uses his judgement to decide whether to add the "other" user (i.e. fred.smith@example.com) to the CC field for that issue. *

A variation of this is that the customer receives the email notification, hasn't got time to respond as they are about to go home, so forwards it to their home email account, then responds to it when they get home. Same result.

We get on average 10 of these per day on SAC.

The problem has the following impact:
- The triage engineer has to manually deal with them.
- We end up with multiple accounts for the same customer. In some cases, this leads to the customer reporting some issues as one user, and some as the other, then complaining that they can't see all their issues when they log in.
- The combination of dealing with the above two points takes the triage engineer on average 1 hour per day.
- We end up with a whole bunch of extra accounts we don't need. If/when we move to a single user base behind SAC, JAC and all our other systems, we (presumably) won't be able to account new accounts from emails anyway, so it is a problem we will have to deal with eventually anyway.

\* If we do add the other user to the CC field (and it is not always the case that we do), we can then re-send the email to JIRA, and the email (and its attachments) will be added to the issue. However the email we need to resend is actually an attachment to the email that is sent to the forward mail box, and the only email client that we are aware of that will allow us to re-send an email attached to another email is ... [mutt|http://www.mutt.org]. Sigh.

h3. The Proposed Solution

1. Add an extra parameter to all the comment email handlers called something like _anonymouscomments_. When _anonymouscomments=true_, if there is not a user in JIRA matching the email address, add the comment anonymously to the issue, with the first line of the comment displaying the email address and, if present, the full name pulled from the email.

Thus, the email is added to the issue as the customer would have wanted. No new user is created in JIRA, so no one who shouldn't have access to JIRA or the issue gets access. The email notification resulting from the new comment is sent out to the correct users.

However, given that the whole world can now add comments to issues in JIRA, this opens the door to spam and denial of service attacks. (Denial of service attacks because unlimited comments added to an issue eventually results in OutOfMemoryErrors.) In order to mitigate these:

2. For the specific case of _anonymouscomments=true_ and there not being a JIRA user with the email address (i.e. when we are about to make an anonymous comment), rather than just matching against issue key in the email subject, also match the remainder of the email subject against the issue summary. If they don't match, don't add a comment and do the normal email error handling/forwarding.

This covers off the case where a malicious somebody with no access to the JIRA instance is just auto-generating issue keys and hammering the JIRA instance with emails with those keys.

3. Add another parameter to all the comment email handlers called something like _maxcomments_. Example usage: _maxcomments=1000_. The mail handler will not add a comment to an issue if there are already <maxcomments> comments on the issue. The JIRA admin could set this to a value higher than you would ever get in normal usage, but less than would start to cause OutOfMemoryErrors or related problems.

*Note:* In discussions about this problem and proposed solution, some people initially suggested that we should also send an email to the user saying that that their email address is different to the one in SAC. I don't think we should do this, as it is our experience of when we have done this when manually handling these problem emails, that this confuses and annoys some users. They don't understand or (legitimately, I feel) don't care. They just want it to work.

We have the same problem on one of our internal Atlassian JIRA instances, and I'm sure that there would be customers who have the same problem and would benefit from the solution.
fields.summary: Allow anonymous comments from email when no matching user

1) Create a project ABC
2) Associate that project with a non-default issue type screen scheme
3) Create a new custom field, e.g. "Import Info", read-only text field
4) Associate "import info" with Default Screen

On my test jira, the customfield is 10170.  Change below as appropriate:

Run the following Jelly:

<JiraJelly xmlns:jira="jelly:com.atlassian.jira.jelly.enterprise.JiraTagLib">
<jira:CreateIssue project-key="ABC" reporter="burkholp" summary="test issue" assignee="-1" duplicateSummary="ignore" issueType="Task" priority="Normal" description="TEST">
<jira:AddCustomFieldValue id="customfield_10160" value="A working custom field" />
<jira:AddCustomFieldValue id="customfield_10170" value="A non-working custom field"/>
</jira:CreateIssue>
</JiraJelly>

The customfield_10170 silently disappears.  It's not only not displayed, but an XML dump of Jira doesn't have it either:

    <CustomFieldValue id="1169575" issue="27115" customfield="10160" stringvalue="A working custom field"/>

(and that's the only CF for issue #27115).

The Jelly run should either add the field value to the issue, or throw an error, but not silently discard it.
fields.summary: Jelly runner silently fails to add custom fields when there's no issue screen associated for that project/cf combination

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-15387].
  {panel}

Background; windows admins often need "special" care and modification of the JIRA service either through the registry entries or passing some parameters to an exe file is often too much for them. 
For ref:
- http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/runasservice.html#N1002C
- http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Setting+properties+and+options+on+startup
Often it is overwhelming, people get the change wrong (typos, wrong service etc) and the cases in SAC are being dragged on unnecessarily. 
Windows user are used to GUI rather than hacks in the registry or commands in the terminal. After all that is why they use Windows not Linux :D

I can recall some cases in SAC where I asked the users why the use WAR in Tomcat rather than the standalone and the answer was "Tomcat has Monitor"

The tool can be used of various things such as adding JVM options, increasing the memory, creating thread dumps; just to name three.

More over, the feature is already out there in any JIRA standalone and by providing access to it, we can greatly improve the user experience. 

!TomcatMonitor.png|thumbnail!

It is enabled by calling {{tomcat5w.exe}} with _MS_ parameter and the service name that you want to connect to. More on that at http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-5.5-doc/windows-service-howto.html

So for e.g. in JIRA the Monitor tool can be started up by executing the following:

"C:\Program Files\JIRA-Professional-3.12.3\bin\tomcat5w.exe" //MS//JIRA120608145928

The monitor can be quite easily configured to be started up on the OS start up by adding the config entry to the registry.
{noformat}
[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run]
"JIRA Monitor"="\"C:\\Program Files\\JIRA-Professional-3.12.3\\bin\\tomcat5w.exe\" //MS//JIRA120608145928"
{noformat}
fields.summary: Enable Tomcat Monitor in JIRA on Windows

To replicate:

1. Select any filter, so the Issue Navigator is shown.
2. Select the "Manage" link.
3. Select the "Subcribe" link on any *other* filter (screenshot-1).

The screen that is shown (screenshot-2) will allow you to set the subscription for the selected filter, which may not be the filter that is shown on the left of the screen. This is very confusing. Would it be possible to fix this by changing the currently selected filter in the session when the user selects the "Subscribe" link?

Watcher management is clunky and not obvious

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-15380].
  {panel}

When posting a comment or making any other change to a bug, there's no immediate indication of who will be sent email as a result.

It's hard for ordinary users to even find out:
  * Watchers are a couple of clicks away
  * It's not obvious whether reporters, commenters, or other people listed directly on the bug page itself will receive comments
  * There can be people who receive email for every bug in a project because of notification schemes

A simple status list just below the comment field listing all the recipients would help alleviate this.
fields.summary: Tell users who notifications will be sent to before the action is performed
Link to download backup file after backup/export has been performed

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-15374].
  {panel}

I'm looking at the very first Jira Setup screen. It'd be cool if all these fields were filled-in by default with some path that might make sense. If we know that certain operating systems like to store data in their own 'favorite places', then we could even default to them, but that's a bit more advanced/headache. We would just need to pick something semi-intelligent -- not / and not /tmp - etc.

http://localhost:8080/secure/Setup.jspa

Also, the backup path with the on/off switch for enabling/disabling backups is not consistent with the ability to add attachments or not. For attachments, if you put in a path, then presumably you've enabled attachments. This is not the case for backups, however. I can understand wanting to stress an explicity On/Off switch with backups, but in the end, I think these settings should be consitent.

So, maybe attachments have their own 'On/Off' radio button, and it is set to 'On' by default, and the path is pre-filled, and if you choose 'Off', then the path box goes grey, and the path disappears from the input box. I notice that the backups path input box gets disabled, as it should, when you choose to disable backups - so that is cool - I wonder if it is possible to grey it out to - change the background color of the now-disabled box to stress that it is disabled, as it is not completely obvious that it is disabled.

After all of this, the only thing I'll have to do for a new install is paste in my license key and click 'Next'.  :)
fields.summary: Would like default 'Index path', 'Attachments path', and 'Backups path' pre-configured and pre-filled in Jira Setup

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-15362].
  {panel}

Currently to perform low level mail debugging you have to set mail.debug=true on the command line and restart JIRA.

We should be able to toggle a switch in the logging section of JIRA and have it turn on dynamically.

Ideally one should only have to set System.getProperties().setProperty*"mail.debug","true") however there is a block on this

In order to get this to work, atlassian-mail needs some surgery as decsribed here: 

http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/MAIL-38

Also in the IMAP/POP fetcher we dont use the same mechanism but instead rely on javax.mail.Session.getDefaultInstance() which is a static.  We need to call setDebug() on this object before using it.

After that we should be able to get dynamic mail debugging in place without a restart.
fields.summary: Add dynamic mail.debug support to JIRA
